content: because you think that there is something separate from the thought thinking the thought, which has to deal with what the thought is describing. there is no potential of harm, there is only a potential for the future (thought) and the potential of harm is for the one who is believed (thought) to be experiencing that thought (the thinker)

why do you think it was suggested to stop thoughts? that rightfully feels off, as it is like trying to stop seeing, hearing, touching, etc. that would not prove anything or provide a solution, because there is nothing in the thought that can harm you. so this would actually serve the belief that thoughts can harm you and that you have to do something about them. you don't have to touch or manipulate thoughts in any way, because what you are is already inherent and true, it doesn't require you to manipulate anything.

understanding a thought doesn't stop thoughts from arising. it is not possible to understand a thought. the one who understands thoughts would be separate from thoughts, thus they would also be a thought as only thoughts create separation like this. a thought can't understand a thought. there is no need to stop thoughts, that is only what your thoughts themselves are telling you.

what you're looking for is already inherent to your experience, so "stopping experience" or changing anything is unnecessary and not inherent.

"you" don't have to do anything, that is also a future extrapolation through thought. there isn't a "you" which can understand a thought or anything like that, as that is also a future extrapolation. none of the mental extrapolating has anything to do with you, those **are** the beliefs, and those **are **self-image. any limit or description you're putting on yourself as a result of inquiry **is not you.**

very simply, you are already there. stick to what is already in your experience. you want what is already absolutely true, not something that will take time and effort. your thoughts are trying to take you somewhere else, by creating "mental carrots" about the future, about your feelings, etc. 

all you have to do is just stay still and watch the thoughts, and by staying still and watching them you realize that your thoughts aren't actually taking you anywhere. you can't mess up being you, why would you think that you can?

The fact of the matter is that you don't see it. So why do you think you can? Because it might appear for you in the future? 

If you're not seeing something, you can only assume that you will see it at some other point. But where's that "you" which is at some other point? And, what other point?

The belief is what you're adding on top of what you're already experiencing. It's not a matter of looking for something that dispels the belief, it's looking at what your belief ***is*** that makes you think that you can see something that isn't there.

Someone who believes in Santa could also use this time component to extrapolate their belief. Maybe they're not experiencing Santa because they haven't searched hard enough? Maybe they'll find Santa in the future? Maybe they just need to wait a bit longer? You're searching for it ***because*** it isn't there ***already.***

In experience, it's already obvious that there isn't Santa. It's the thoughts which aren't experienced that you're adding on top of experience, which perpetuates the belief. Otherwise, experience is self-evident. Thoughts aren't self-evident, because they conceptually extrapolate into the future, which ***never is***, ***by design.*** It's like constantly trying to get the perfect weather prediction - it makes no sense. 

Otherwise, your experience is quite clear about it. It isn't there, you're the one assuming that it is, hence the search. You don't search for something if it's already in your experience, you search for it because you assume it exists somewhere else. This assumption is the thought you recognize yourself in. 

Because there is only current experience, the fact of experience is that it isn't there, but you are imagining yourself in a future where it is there. You've created a concept for yourself that perpetuates itself as long as you believe in someone who experiences a future, but you have ***never experienced that.*** 

This is what the entire search is. The search is for the one in the future, that the one which is now never experiences. This is by design, as it actually points to the truth of yourself, that you are always now. Someone who is now couldn't know anything about someone who is not now.

its important to notice that you didn't learn more about santa to get rid of him. learning more about santa ensconces you further into the belief. theres no method, knowledge, technique, etc, for getting rid of santa because those would all perpetuate the belief in santa, theres only realizing they arent there because they are a belief. You don't have to go and hunt santa down. a newborn doesnt have to learn or think or gain new knowledge to realize santa isn't there, because santa isn't there.

what happened was you gained a piece of knowledge from google maps about santa, and then used it to recognize your experience, like "i live in a world where santa is real" and then you replaced that belief with some piece of knowledge or evidence that counteracts it, so now you can recognize yourself in this newly found piece of evidence or knowledge like "i live in a world where santa doesnt exist because it's actually my parents doing that and I have memories of that etc. etc.". You are recognizing yourself in knowledge and trying to update your current experience of that knowledge, which is like fighting beliefs with beliefs, which is the basis of self-image. 

Similarly, like learning about santa ensconces you further into santa, trying to refine how you think of yourself ensconces you further into self-image. You can't think of yourself because you can't think of yourself thinking, this is the recursiveness again.

in regards to figuring out the experience of santa, notice that these theories are all models to answer the question "what am i actually experiencing?", but they are part of what you are currently experiencing. this present moment "modelling" is called "thinking".

if you noticed, the "I" which is trying to figure out what they are experiencing is actually contained in the question "what am I actually experiencing?", and so the question implies that you are trying to recognize your experience of yourself in the thought/knowledge/appearance which is supposed to answer that question. So if you answer "I'm experiencing santa claus", you now "recognize yourself" in that piece of knowledge which you currently modeled. Like yes, that's me, I am the one experiencing that. This is, again, the recursiveness.

There isn't a separate "you" left behind from the past or future that you have to have knowledge about, the current knowledge models any idea of past or future, currently. There isn't a "you" at the effect of the model, as that would be something separate from the model, there is only the model (thinking) currently appearing.

> I don't know if this makes any sense to ask, but what does the self-image supposedly explain that it doesn't actually explain? 

The self-image plays a lose-lose game because it's trying to explain something that simply isn't there.

Self-image is a recursive thought that refers to a separate self when there is none, which you recognize yourself in. That is the belief. 

Self-image continuously appears as problems, fears, solutions, explanations, etc,*** for*** this separate self ***until*** it is noticed that there isn't a separate self which is separate from the problems, fears, solutions, and explanations which your thoughts are presently appearing as.

You aren't defining it as something that doesn't exist, though. You think it does exist even though it doesn't exist. That is the nature of belief. 

You aren't "finding self-image", you're trying to figure out why "it" isn't there in the first place (the thoughts that you recognize yourself in). 

If someone tells me they believe in Santa, and then upon questioning they can't tell me what Santa looks like or even define what Santa is in the first place, then this is only problematic for someone who believes in Santa, but quite silly to someone who doesn't because they look at it and say "yeah I mean he probably isn't there", but the person who believes in it is gonna be sitting there confused because they haven't completely examined the belief yet. If they completely examine it, they will realize it doesn't exist, and will stop engaging with it.

The person who lets go of thoughts is the one who would be separate of thoughts. How can a thought let go of a thought, unless you believe something in the thought is separate from the thought?

Following the method of bringing the belief to the limelight...

First find the person who has to let go of thoughts before trying to get rid of them

If you can't find them, then there is no actual identifiable "problem" until you do

there is a recursive aspect of the thoughts (as described before, the "me" that thinks) that is causing this elusive feeling of fearing what is "behind the thought". 

The reason why you fear the thoughts about yourself is because you're ***thinking*** of something separate from the thought that has to deal with the thought, but it's actually part of the thought. No one has to deal with the future because no one is thinking about the future. "I am thinking about the future" is a thought that no one is thinking. 

The "bear" is the "me who might experience something scary in the future", checking the closet is seeing that there isn't a bear (thinker) to begin with, and thus no one at effect of the thought in the first place. phew!

so to speak, if you deal with the belief in the bear (thinker, separate "me"), it wont appear in any of your other thoughts (closets) anymore

it means that you are holding a thought in your experience and identifying with what it is displaying. you're "recognizing yourself" in the same way how you might look at a mirror and say "thats me!", and in the same way how you might think about the future and say "thats me who has to experience that future!". All your thoughts about the future ***seem to*** denote someone who has to worry about or experience the future, but that is the separation and it is the recursive "thinker" that isn't there.

when you ask "how do i tell?", that would go back to what i said about bringing the belief to the limelight. You think you can experience the future, why? What even is the future, in your experience? etc. These questions bring the belief to the limelight for scrutiny, which is what self-inquiry is.

using the mirror analogy, questioning the belief would be like asking "why do you think you're inside the mirror?"

then you might say something like, "well it looks like me and mimics me"

then you might say "well that doesn't necessarily mean it is me, does it? and then also, how are there two of me?"

then you keep going and you'll realize that all your conclusions are off and don't really land anywhere or define you at any point, which rids you of the belief

It's the thought or belief which is currently appearing which is being felt emotionally. You don't feel tomorrow, you feel the belief in tomorrow. And that is part of the thought you are having now. If you believe there is a bear in your closet, that belief does not require a bear, it only requires the assumption that there is one, and that assumption feels like fear.

There isn't a separate "me" to examine, that is correct. What is happening is that you are having a thought about the future and you are recognizing yourself in that thought, like looking at a reflection in the mirror, and you are reacting emotionally to it.

"Me who is worried about the future" isn't separate from the thought of the future, it is the thought. The thought of the future feels like worry, which is to say, it is identical to worry. And that presently appearing thought, if examined, will show that there is no "you" separate from the thought that has to worry about the thought of the future. 

You are essentially creating a recursion in thought. You are thinking of the person who is thinking and then worrying about them, but no one is thinking that thought.

Beliefs are concepts that aren't experienced, just like the concepts of "tomorrow" or "non-existence". The function of thinking allows you to think of things that you don't experience.

Nonetheless, though there aren't beliefs, as in, there isn't what the concept is pointing to, there is how that belief or concept feels presently.

For example, anxiety is how the belief that you can experience the future feels (fear, presently).

The fact of the matter is, you think that you are a separate entity that is experiencing the implications of your thoughts (tomorrow, non-existence, etc.). This is the belief which is felt currently, as aversive emotions like fear. The feelings and emotions aren't beliefs, and they aren't caused by beliefs. In the same way that the fear of Santa isn't actually caused by Santa. And in the same way that the fear of tomorrow isn't actually caused by tomorrow, because fear occurs now, not tomorrow.

https://discord.com/channels/1129343306485215342/1129343306485215345/1297680547421884466

The way for you to dispel the belief is simply to find it. You believe it exists. Where is it? What does it look like? Do you have any memories of it? Bring it to the limelight. First find the belief and figure out what it is before trying to get rid of it. The disillusionment happens naturally when all your attempts at experiencing the belief fail, leading you to recognize that perhaps it doesn't exist at all and that your way of looking at it is mistaken in some way.

In regards to "non-psychological fear", you experience this in various degrees too. It happens exactly like getting startled by a loud sound. It's just your body reacting to your environment, without any need for mental distinguishing. You don't think "I'm gonna be scared of a loud sound", you just hear it without any prediction and react to it.
